intro: Cinchona barbacoensis, commonly known as the Peruvian bark or quina, is a species of tree native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and yellow flowers. The plant is renowned for its production of quinine, a compound historically used to treat malaria. Its bark contains high concentrations of alkaloids, which contribute to its medicinal significance. Cinchona barbacoensis typically grows in humid, shaded environments at elevations between 1,000 and 2,500 meters.
